content: 12 So, here is what you must do: because you desire that the Holy Spirit specially empowers you, you should strive more and more {to use what the Holy Spirit empowers you to do} to help the group of believers become stronger.

title: 1 Corinthians 14:13
content: 13 Therefore, those who talk in unknown languages should ask God to enable them to explain {what they are saying}.

title: 1 Corinthians 14:14
content: 14 When I{, for example,} pray {to God} in an unknown language, only part of me is praying since I am not thinking about what I am saying.

title: 1 Corinthians 14:15
content: 15 Therefore, here is what {you and I should do}. We should pray {to God} not only with just some parts of us but also by thinking about what we are saying. We should sing {to God} not only with just some parts of us but also by thinking about what we are singing.

title: 1 Corinthians 14:16
content: 16 Imagine that people who do not understand {unknown languages} hear you praising God when you are using just some parts of you{, and you are not thinking about what you are saying}. Those people will not be able to participate when you praise God because they do not understand {the unknown language} that you are speaking.

title: 1 Corinthians 14:17
content: 17 In this situation, you praise God appropriately. However, you do not help other people become stronger.

title: 1 Corinthians 14:18
content: 18 I give thanks to God that I talk in unknown languages more than you all do.

title: 1 Corinthians 14:19
content: 19 However, when I gather together with fellow believers to worship God, I want to speak only a few words that I think about. In this way, I can teach other believers and {not just myself}. {It is better for me to do that} than {to say} a million words in an unknown language.

title: 1 Corinthians 14:20
content: 20 My fellow believers, I do not want you to be foolish {about these things, like} little children {are}. Rather, you should know much {about these things, like} a fully grown adult {does}. You should {only} be {like} little children by not doing what is wrong.

title: 1 Corinthians 14:21
content: 21 The prophet Isaiah wrote in the Scriptures what the Lord says, “I will talk to my people Israel by means of people who speak foreign languages. However, they will not listen to me in this way.”

title: 1 Corinthians 14:22
content: 22 Therefore, talking in unknown languages signifies that God judges people who do not believe {in the Messiah}, not people who do believe {in the Messiah}. On the other hand, proclaiming what God says {signifies that God acts kindly toward} people who believe {in the Messiah}, not toward people who do not believe {in the Messiah}.

title: 1 Corinthians 14:23
content: 23 So, imagine that the whole group of believers gathered together to worship God, and all of you talked in unknown languages. Imagine further that people who do not understand {unknown languages} or who do not believe {in the Messiah} visit your group. They will tell {others} that you are crazy.

title: 1 Corinthians 14:24
content: 24 On the other hand, imagine that all of you proclaimed what God says. Imagine further that any people who do not believe {in the Messiah} or who do not understand {unknown languages} visit your group. Everything that you say will show them and confront them with {what they have done wrong}.

title: 1 Corinthians 14:25
content: 25 {In this way,} everyone will know the things that these {visitors} hide from others. In response, they will kneel down and worship God. They will proclaim {to others} that God truly is with you.

title: 1 Corinthians 14:26
content: 26 My fellow believers, here is what I mean. Whenever you gather together {to worship God}, each believer {has something to do}. Some sing songs, others teach, others reveal things, others speak in an unknown language, others interpret an unknown language. Believers should do all these things to help other believers become stronger.

title: 1 Corinthians 14:27
content: 27 When believers are talking in unknown languages, only two or three at most {should speak}. They should talk one after the other, and someone needs to explain {what they are saying}.

title: 1 Corinthians 14:28
content: 28 On the other hand, when believers gather to worship God and a person who can explain the unknown language is not there, everyone who can talk in unknown languages should keep quiet. Instead {of talking out loud}, they should talk {in unknown languages} privately to God.

title: 1 Corinthians 14:29
content: 29 Similarly, {around} two or three people who proclaim what God says should speak. Everyone else should decide whether {what they say} is correct or incorrect.

title: 1 Corinthians 14:30
content: 30 Now, whenever God reveals something to a person who is listening {to someone else proclaim what God says when believers gather together}, the person who is speaking should stop speaking.

title: 1 Corinthians 14:31
content: 31 {You should do that} so that everyone has a chance to proclaim what God says, one after the other. In that way, everyone learns something, and everyone becomes stronger.

title: 1 Corinthians 14:32
content: 32 Those who proclaim what God says control how and when they proclaim it.

title: 1 Corinthians 14:33
content: 33 {That is true} because what is peaceful and orderly, not what is disorderly, characterizes God. {I want you to act} like all the {other} people whom God has set apart for himself act when they gather together to worship God.

title: 1 Corinthians 14:34
content: 34 Wives should keep quiet when believers gather together {and their husbands are speaking}. They should not talk but rather honor and obey {their husbands}. {They should do this} because that is what we find in {God’s} law.

title: 1 Corinthians 14:35
content: 35 Now, when wives want to learn more {about what their husbands are saying}, they should ask their husbands questions in their own houses. {They should do this} because wives who talk when believers gather together {and their husbands are speaking} shame {themselves and their families}.

title: 1 Corinthians 14:36
content: 36 {If you dislike what I have said,} remember that you are not the source of what God has said, and you are not the only ones who have heard {and believed what God has said}.

title: 1 Corinthians 14:37
content: 37 All people who consider themselves to be those who proclaim what God says or those whom the Holy Spirit has specially empowered must recognize that the Lord himself requires what I am writing to you.

title: 1 Corinthians 14:38
content: 38 On the other hand, you should not recognize {as authoritative} any people who do not recognize {that the Lord requires what I have said}.

title: 1 Corinthians 14:39
content: 39 In the end, my fellow believers, eagerly seek to proclaim what God says. Further, do not prohibit people from speaking unknown languages.

title: 1 Corinthians 14:40
content: 40 Finally, {when you gather together to worship God}, you should always act in honorable and orderly ways.

title: 1 Corinthians 15:1
content: 1 Next, I am informing you, fellow believers, about the good news that I told you about. You learned this good news {from me}, and you firmly believe it.

title: 1 Corinthians 15:2
content: 2 When you continue to firmly believe the message that I preached to you, God saves you by means of that message. Otherwise, you believed {the message} for nothing.

title: 1 Corinthians 15:3
content: 3 Here is one of the first things that I told you, which I learned {from the Lord}: the Messiah died {on the cross} to take away our sins, just as {the authors of} the holy books {wrote}.

title: 1 Corinthians 15:4
content: 4 People buried him, but during the third day {after that}, God made him alive again, just as {the authors of} the holy books {wrote}.

title: 1 Corinthians 15:5
content: 5 He appeared to Peter and then to the {rest of Jesus’} 12 {closest followers}.

title: 1 Corinthians 15:6
content: 6 After that, he appeared at one time to greater than 500 fellow believers. Although some of these people have died, almost all of them are still alive.

title: 1 Corinthians 15:7
content: 7 After that, he appeared to James and then to everyone whom he sent to represent him.

title: 1 Corinthians 15:8
content: 8 Finally, after he appeared to all of them, he appeared to me also. So, {because I became one whom Jesus sent to represent him after everyone else}, I am like a baby that was born in an unusual way.

title: 1 Corinthians 15:9
content: 9 In fact, I am less significant and honorable than every other person whom the Messiah sent to represent him. Indeed, since I tried to destroy those who believe in the Messiah, I do not deserve it when others call me one whom the Messiah sent to represent him.

title: 1 Corinthians 15:10
content: 10 However, God graciously made me one whom the Messiah sent to represent him. Further, what he has given me has resulted in great things. In fact, I worked harder than all the other {ones whom the Messiah sent to represent him}. Of course, it was not really I {who worked so hard}. Instead, it was God graciously working through me {who did so much}.

title: 1 Corinthians 15:11
content: 11 In the end, both I and the other apostles proclaim the good news that I have described, and you trusted this good news.

title: 1 Corinthians 15:12
content: 12 Because all believers say that God made the Messiah alive again, no one in your group should be claiming that people who have died will not live again.

title: 1 Corinthians 15:13
content: 13 Suppose {that it were true} that people who have died will not live again. {In that case,} God did not make the Messiah alive again.

title: 1 Corinthians 15:14
content: 14 Suppose {that it is true} that God did not make the Messiah alive again. In that case, it was for no reason that we proclaimed {the good news} and you believed it.

title: 1 Corinthians 15:15
content: 15 Further, we would be people who tell lies about God, because we declared before God that he made the Messiah alive again when he really did not. This would all be true were God not to make those who have died alive again.

title: 1 Corinthians 15:16
content: 16 {You can tell that this is true when you} suppose that God does not make people who have died alive again. {In that case,} God did not make even the Messiah alive again.

title: 1 Corinthians 15:17
content: 17 Suppose {that it is true} that God did not make the Messiah alive again. {In that case,} you believed {the good news} for no reason, and sin continues to control you.

title: 1 Corinthians 15:18
content: 18 In that case again, the believers who have died will never live again.

title: 1 Corinthians 15:19
content: 19 Suppose that we can confidently expect the Messiah {to help us} only before we die. {In that case,} all people should feel sorry for us more than {they feel sorry} for anyone else.

title: 1 Corinthians 15:20
content: 20 But here is what is true: God has made the Messiah alive again, and he is the first of those who have died {whom God will make alive again}.

title: 1 Corinthians 15:21
content: 21 {You can tell that this is true,} because people die through what the one man {Adam} did. So also people who have died will live again through what the one man {Jesus} did.

title: 1 Corinthians 15:22
content: 22 What I mean is that, just as all people end up dying because God united them to Adam, in the same way all {believers} will live again because God unites them to the Messiah.

title: 1 Corinthians 15:23
content: 23 Now, all people {who will live again} do so in turn: first the Messiah and then those who belong to the Messiah when he comes {back again}.

title: 1 Corinthians 15:24
content: 24 After that, what everything that God has created is waiting for {will happen}. At that time, the Messiah will get rid of everyone and everything that rules and governs and controls. Then, he will present God, {who is our} Father, with the kingdom {so that God rules over everything}.

title: 1 Corinthians 15:25
content: 25 Here is how {that works}: God has decided that the Messiah will rule until whenever he has conquered all those who oppose him.

title: 1 Corinthians 15:26
content: 26 The last thing that opposes Christ that he will get rid of is that people die.

title: 1 Corinthians 15:27
content: 27 Now, {David wrote,} “he made him conquer everything that opposes him.” Of course, “everything” does not include God, who is the one who “made him conquer everything.”

title: 1 Corinthians 15:28
content: 28 So, after he has conquered everything, then God the Son will submit to the one who made him conquer everything. In this way, God will conquer and rule all things.

title: 1 Corinthians 15:29
content: 29 Now, consider people who baptize others to help those who are dead. Further, suppose again that God never makes people who have died alive again. {In that case,} there is no reason for people to baptize others to help those who have died.

title: 1 Corinthians 15:30
content: 30 Even more, {in that case,} there is no reason for we {who proclaim the good news} to constantly endanger ourselves {as we do}.

title: 1 Corinthians 15:31
content: 31 Indeed, I risk dying very frequently. I swear {that this is true} by how I boast about you, fellow believers, which I do because God has united all of us to the Messiah, {who is} Jesus our Lord.

title: 1 Corinthians 15:32
content: 32 Suppose that I was thinking about merely human things while I struggled against those who opposed me when I visited the city of Ephesus. {In that case, struggling against them} does not benefit me at all. Suppose again that God does not make people who have died alive again. {In that case,} we should {do what many people say to do}: eat {food}, and drink {wine}, because we will die very soon.

title: 1 Corinthians 15:33
content: 33 You should not believe what is wrong. {This popular saying is true:} “Evil friends lead astray a person who normally does what is proper.”

title: 1 Corinthians 15:34
content: 34 I want you to start acting alertly and properly. You should not keep doing what is wrong. {I command these things} because some people in your group do not know God. I say that in order to make you feel ashamed

title: 1 Corinthians 15:35
content: 35 Now a person may ask about the way in which the people who have died live again and about what form they will take.

title: 1 Corinthians 15:36
content: 36 {If you do not know the answers to those questions,} you are not thinking clearly! {Just think about this:} a seed that you put in the ground must die before it can grow.

title: 1 Corinthians 15:37
content: 37 {Speaking about} a seed that you put in the ground, {you know that} it is not in the form of the plant. Rather, it is just the seed. This is true whether {we are speaking about} wheat or some other crop.

title: 1 Corinthians 15:38
content: 38 Indeed, God makes seeds grow into the forms that he chooses, and each kind of seed has a specific form {into which it grows}.

title: 1 Corinthians 15:39
content: 39 The physical parts of different living beings vary. For example, humans, mammals, birds, and fish all have different kinds of physical parts.

title: 1 Corinthians 15:40
content: 40 Some things exist in heaven, and other things exist on earth. The forms of things in heaven are glorious in one way, while the forms of things on earth are glorious in another way.

title: 1 Corinthians 15:41
content: 41 {Further,} the sun, moon, and stars are glorious in different ways. In fact, each star is glorious in its own specific way.

title: 1 Corinthians 15:42
content: 42 Here is the way {all that applies to how} people who have died live again. People put a decaying body into the ground, but God makes it alive again so that it can never die.

title: 1 Corinthians 15:43
content: 43 People put a body that receives no respect into the ground, but God makes it alive again so that everyone respects it. People put a frail body into the ground, but God makes it alive again so that it is strong.

title: 1 Corinthians 15:44
content: 44 People put a body that belongs to this world into the ground, but God makes it alive again so that it belongs to the world that God will renew. Just as some bodies belong to this world, so some bodies belong to the world that God will renew.

title: 1 Corinthians 15:45
content: 45 {You can tell that this is true} because Moses wrote, “God made the first human, Adam, as a living being who belonged to this world.” {On the other hand, Jesus, who is like} another Adam, now belongs to the world that God will renew and gives life to others.

title: 1 Corinthians 15:46
content: 46 Now {the first Adam’s} body that belongs to this world existed first, and only after that does {the last Adam’s body} exist that belongs to the world that God will renew.

title: 1 Corinthians 15:47
content: 47 {Adam, who represents} the first {kind of} human, belonged on the earth. {In fact,} God made him from dust. {On the other hand, Jesus, who represents} the second {kind of} human, belongs in heaven.

title: 1 Corinthians 15:48
content: 48 All people who belong on the earth are like Adam. All those who belong in heaven are like Jesus.

title: 1 Corinthians 15:49
content: 49 Our bodies currently are like {Adam’s body} that belongs to this world. In the same way, we should live in such a way that our bodies will eventually be like {Jesus’ body,} which belongs to the world that God will renew.

title: 1 Corinthians 15:50
content: 50 Listen to this, my fellow believers: human bodies as they currently exist cannot participate in God’s kingdom that lasts forever, since they fall apart and die.

title: 1 Corinthians 15:51
content: 51 Pay attention! I am going to tell you something that God has now revealed. Not all of us will die, but God will transform all of us.

title: 1 Corinthians 15:52
content: 52 {He will transform us} in one moment, as fast as a person blinks an eye. {This will happen} when {an angel blows} the trumpet that signals that this world is ending. When {an angel} blows that trumpet, God will make those who have died live again so that they can never die, and he will transform everyone who still lives.

title: 1 Corinthians 15:53
content: 53 So, bodies that fall apart and die need to transform into bodies that last forever and can never die.

title: 1 Corinthians 15:54
content: 54 When our bodies that fall apart and die transform into bodies that last forever and can never die, at that time what the prophets wrote about will finally happen: “God has made it so that people no longer die.”

title: 1 Corinthians 15:55
content: 55 {Further,} “When people die, this does not destroy or hurt them.”

title: 1 Corinthians 15:56
content: 56 People die because sin causes them to die, and that happens because the law specifies dying as the penalty for sin.

title: 1 Corinthians 15:57
content: 57 However, I praise God because he has enabled us to conquer {how we sin and die}. {He has done this} by means of what our Lord, Jesus the Messiah, has done.

title: 1 Corinthians 15:58
content: 58 So then, fellow believers whom I love, firmly believe {what you know is true}. Consistently serve the Lord more and more. {You should do these things} because you know that what you do {to serve the Lord} will result in great things, since God has united you to the Lord.

title: 1 Corinthians 16:1
content: 1 I am now moving on to speak about the money that I am collecting for God’s people {who are Jewish}. I want you to do what I instructed the groups of believers {who live} in the region of Galatia to do.

title: 1 Corinthians 16:2
content: 2 During each Sunday, every one of you should take some money out of whatever you have earned and save it. That way, I will not need to collect money when I visit you.

title: 1 Corinthians 16:3
content: 3 Choose some trustworthy people from your group. When I visit you, I will have them take the money {that you have collected} to the city of Jerusalem. Also, I will give them letters {that say that I have authorized them}.

title: 1 Corinthians 16:4
content: 4 You and I may decide that I should go {to Jerusalem} as well. In that case, the people {whom you choose} will travel with me.

title: 1 Corinthians 16:5
content: 5 I am going to visit you after I travel through the region of Macedonia, which is the way I will be traveling.

title: 1 Corinthians 16:6
content: 6 In fact, I may spend some time with you, maybe the whole winter. That way, you can assist me in traveling to wherever I decide to go next.

title: 1 Corinthians 16:7
content: 7 {I am making these plans} because I would rather wait to be with you for a long time than visit you right now for just a short time. I confidently expect to do this as long as it is what the Lord wants {me to do}.

title: 1 Corinthians 16:8
content: 8 For now, I plan on remaining here in the city of Ephesus until the Pentecost festival.

title: 1 Corinthians 16:9
content: 9 {I am remaining here} because God has allowed me to effectively and freely proclaim the good news. {Further, I need to resist} the large number of people who are working against me.

title: 1 Corinthians 16:10
content: 10 Whenever Timothy arrives {in your city}, make sure that he feels safe when he is with you. {You should do this} because he serves the Lord {by proclaiming the good news}, just like I do.

title: 1 Corinthians 16:11
content: 11 So, do not treat him disrespectfully. Rather, act in a friendly way by assisting him in traveling back to me. {You should do this} because I anticipate that he will come back to me with the other believers {who are traveling to visit me}.

title: 1 Corinthians 16:12
content: 12 I am now moving on to speak about our fellow believer, Apollos. I firmly urged him to visit you with the other believers {who were traveling to visit you}. However, he firmly decided that it was not the right time to visit you. Instead, he will visit you when he thinks that it is the right time.

title: 1 Corinthians 16:13
content: 13 Watch out {for what is wrong}! Firmly believe {the good news}! Be courageous! Be determined!

title: 1 Corinthians 16:14
content: 14 You should focus on loving others whenever you think or do anything.

title: 1 Corinthians 16:15
content: 15 You know that those who live in the house of Stephanas were the first people {to believe the good news} in the region of Achaia. Further, they have chosen to serve God’s people. I ask you, my fellow believers,

title: 1 Corinthians 16:16
content: 16 to honor and obey them and other people like them. In fact, {you should honor and obey} every person who works hard {to proclaim the good news} with us.

title: 1 Corinthians 16:17
content: 17 I am happy that Stephanas, Fortunatus, and Achaicus arrived here. {That is} because they have allowed me to connect with you all even when you are not with me.

title: 1 Corinthians 16:18
content: 18 They encouraged and energized both me and you. Therefore, you should honor them and other people like them.

title: 1 Corinthians 16:19
content: 19 The groups of believers here in the region of Asia say hello to you. Aquila and Priscilla, as those whom God has also united to the Lord, say hello to you affectionately. The believers that gather in their house {also say hello to you}.

title: 1 Corinthians 16:20
content: 20 All the fellow believers {who are with me} say hello to you. Welcome each other in a loving way.

title: 1 Corinthians 16:21
content: 21 I, Paul, say hello {to you}. I am writing {these last words} myself {instead of having my scribe write them}.

title: 1 Corinthians 16:22
content: 22 May God curse everyone who fails to love the Lord. I pray that the Lord returns soon.

title: 1 Corinthians 16:23
content: 23 {I pray that} the Lord Jesus will be gracious to you.

title: 1 Corinthians 16:24
content: 24 I continue to love all of you, since God has united us together with Jesus the Messiah. May it be so!
